prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We choose our representative spectral window resolution carefully so that there are at least three resolution elements, allowing measuring the shape of the line profile. The proposed line is fully covered in the spectral windows.

The requested angular resolution of 0.3" yields a linear scale of 2.5 kpc at z~1.5. Given the nature of these dwarf galaxies, we suspect the largest scale will be > 10kpc. We use the estimated half-light radii of 1.5"(~12 kpc) from Masters et al. 2014 as the nominal largest scale for the source. Note that this value is still smaller than the theta_MRS = 4.2" for C36-4 or more extended configuration up to C36-6 at B6. The largest scale does not change the total time, because ACA is not needed. By making this choice, we could still get a detection if the line spreads over 2 beams within the central 20kpc. This resolution allows measuring the size of the CO gas (tracing SF).

This target has precise spectroscopic redshifts from high resolution Magellan FIRE spectroscopy, thus well defined sky frequencies of the selected CO transitions. We select the CO 5-4 transition for WISP9_73 (z=1.454) in Baseband-1, and enter the manually selected frequency for additional continuum observations.
We estimate the conservative CO line intensities (I_CO) and luminosity (L'_CO) by combining Solomon \& Vanden Bout (2005) results for star forming galaxies and the Kennicut-Schmidt law (See Science Justification for equation used). These estimates are consistent with the values given in Genzel et al. 2012 based on SFR, metallicity and half-light radius of the source, using a 'n' index of 1.1. The CO line intensities are given in Table 1 and derived from the extinction corrected SFR (Masters et al.2014).
CO line intensities are used to estimate their signal-to-noise ratios (S/N) at the requested sensitivity of 0.35 mJy. Though we aim for a detection, with a proposed spectral resolution of 50km/s the CO lines will spread over 3.7 spectral resolution elements for a line FWHM=186 km/s, allowing resolved line profile. The FWHM is estimated from the H_alpha velocity dispersion from Masters et al. 2014. A lower FWHM will result in higher S/N detection but will result in a partially or unresolved line profile. At the requested sensitivity, we will still achieve a S/N of > 5 of the CO emission in the case the line is resolved.
The continuum values are nominal as it is not our science goal to detect the continuum. The requested angular resolution of 0.3" yields a linear scale of 2.5 kpc at z~1.5, 2 times larger than the estimated half-light radii. Therefore the S/N estimate will remain valid within the ALMA beam.

In this case the intrinsic line width is too narrow and not resolvable even by the finest spectral window resolution in this band. We would not be able to resolve the lines but rather only get a detection. The ratio is still close to 3, allowing the line to be partially resolved. CO line of another transition is available for the same source at a different band.

The requested angular resolution of 0.5" yields a linear scale of 4.3 kpc at z~1.5. Given the nature of these dwarf galaxies, we suspect the largest scale will be > 10kpc. We use the estimated half-light radii of 1.5"(~12 kpc) from Masters et al. 2014 as the nominal largest scale for the source. Note that this value is still smaller than the theta_MRS = 6.4" for C36-4 or more extended configuration up to C36-7 at B4 and does not change the total time, because ACA is not needed. By making this choice, we could still get a detection if the line spreads over 2 beams within the central 20kpc. This resolution allows measuring the size of the CO gas (tracing SF).

The FWHM is estimated from the H_alpha velocity dispersion from Masters et al. 2014. A lower FWHM will result in higher S/N detection but will result in a partially or unresolved line profile. At the requested sensitivity, we will still achieve a S/N ~3 detection of the CO emission in the case the line is resolved.

We use the estimated half-light radii of 2.0"(~17 kpc) from Masters et al. 2014 as the nominal largest scale for the source. Note that this value is still smaller than the theta_MRS = 9.6" for C36-4 or more extended configuration up to C36-7 at B4 and does not change the total time, because ACA is not needed. This target has precise spectroscopic redshifts from high resolution Magellan FIRE spectroscopy, thus well defined sky frequencies of the selected CO transitions. We select the CO 3-2 transition for WISP27_95 (z=2.192) in Baseband-1, and enter the manually selected frequency for additional continuum observations.
We estimate the conservative CO line intensities (I_CO) and luminosity (L'_CO) by combining Solomon \& Vanden Bout (2005) results for star forming galaxies and the Kennicut-Schmidt law (See Science Justification for equation used). These estimates are consistent with the values given in Genzel et al. 2012 based on SFR, metallicity and half-light radius of the source, using a 'n' index of 1.1. The CO line intensities are given in Table 1 and derived from the extinction corrected SFR (Masters et al.2014).
CO line intensities are used to estimate their signal-to-noise ratios (S/N) at the requested sensitivity of 0.3 mJy. Though we aim for a detection, with a proposed spectral resolution of 60km/s the CO lines will spread across ~3 spectral resolution elements for a line FWHM=260 km/s, allowing resolved line profile. The FWHM is estimated from the H_alpha velocity dispersion from Masters et al. 2014. A lower FWHM will result in higher S/N detection but will result in a partially or unresolved line profile. If the line is fainter than predicted, we will smooth the sensitivity bandwidth to look for a S/N > 3 detection.
The continuum values are nominal as it is not our science goal to detect the continuum. The requested angular resolution of 0.7" yields a linear scale of 6 kpc at z~2.2, 3 times larger than the estimated half-light radii. Therefore the S/N estimate will remain valid within the ALMA beam.

We choose our representative spectral window resolution carefully so that there are at least three resolution elements, allowing measuring the shape of the line profile. The proposed line is fully covered in the spectral windows.

The requested angular resolution of 0.5" yields a linear scale of 4.2 kpc at z~2.2. Given the nature of these dwarf galaxies, we suspect the largest scale will be > 10kpc. We use the estimated half-light radii of 2"(~17 kpc) from Masters et al. 2014 as the nominal largest scale for the source. Note that this value is still smaller than the theta_MRS = 6.4" for C36-4 or more extended configuration up to C36-7 at B4 and does not change the total time, because ACA is not needed. By making this choice, we could still get a detection if the line spreads over 2 beams within the central 20kpc. This resolution allows measuring the size of the CO gas (tracing SF).

Though we aim for a detection, with a proposed spectral resolution of 60km/s the CO lines will spread over 4 spectral resolution elements for a line FWHM=260 km/s, allowing resolved line profile. The FWHM is estimated from the H_alpha velocity dispersion from Masters et al. 2014. A lower FWHM will result in higher S/N detection but will result in a partially or unresolved line profile. If the line is as fainter than predicted, we will smooth the sensitivity bandwidth to look for a S/N > 3 detection.
The continuum values are nominal as it is not our science goal to detect the continuum. The requested angular resolution of 0.5" yields a linear scale of 4.3 kpc at z~2.2, 2 times larger than the estimated half-light radii. Therefore the S/N estimate will remain valid within the ALMA beam.

By making this choice, we could still get a detection if the line spreads over 2 beams within the central 20kpc. This resolution allows measuring the size of the CO gas (tracing SF).

The requested angular resolution of 0.7" yields a linear scale of 6 kpc at z~2.2. Given the nature of these dwarf galaxies, we suspect the largest scale will be > 10kpc. We use the estimated half-light radii of 2.4"(~20 kpc) from Masters et al. 2014 as the nominal largest scale for the source. Note that this value is still smaller than the theta_MRS = 9.6" for C36-4 or more extended configuration up to C36-7 at B4 and does not change the total time, because ACA is not needed. This target has precise spectroscopic redshifts from high resolution Magellan FIRE spectroscopy, thus well defined sky frequencies of the selected CO transitions. We select the CO 3-2 transition for WISP96_58 (z=2.234) in Baseband-1, and enter the manually selected frequency for additional continuum observations.
We estimate the conservative CO line intensities (I_CO) and luminosity (L'_CO) by combining Solomon \& Vanden Bout (2005) results for star forming galaxies and the Kennicut-Schmidt law (See Science Justification for equation used). These estimates are consistent with the values given in Genzel et al. 2012 based on SFR, metallicity and half-light radius of the source, using a 'n' index of 1.1. The CO line intensities are given in Table 1 and derived from the extinction corrected SFR (Masters et al.2014).
CO line intensities are used to estimate their signal-to-noise ratios (S/N) at the requested sensitivity of 0.3 mJy. We aim for a detection, and at this settings we cannot resolve a line with FWHM=120 km/s. The FWHM is estimated from the H_alpha velocity dispersion from Masters et al. 2014. A lower FWHM will result in higher S/N detection but the line will stay unresolved. If the line is as fainter than predicted, we will smooth the sensitivity bandwidth to look for a S/N > 3 detection.
The continuum values are nominal as it is not our science goal to detect the continuum. The requested angular resolution of 0.7" yields a linear scale of 6 kpc at z~2.2, 3 times larger than the estimated half-light radii. Therefore the S/N estimate will remain valid within the ALMA beam.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: There is strong disagreement between observations and theoretical predictions for the evolution of the molecular gas fraction. The large uncertainties in M(H2) at high-z are probably partially responsible for this tension. Genzel et al. (2012) recently showed that commonly used values for the CO to H2 conversion factor (alpha_CO, valid for local MW-like and starburst galaxies) may result in a significant underestimate of the real H2 mass, due to a much higher alpha_CO at lower metallicities. Covering a small range of metallicity, Genzel et al. could not accurately constrain the slope of the alpha_CO-Z relation. In this program, we will extend the Genzel et al. measurements to galaxies with a factor of two lower metallicities. We request 10.7 hours, to observe six galaxies at z=1.5 - 2.2 in CO(3-2, 4-3, 5-4) emission lines. The targets have well constrained oxygen abundances, stellar masses and SFRs. Together with our multi-band HST imaging, the proposed observations will allow us to measure: 1) alpha-CO in low-mass, low metallicity galaxies, 2) the molecular-gas depletion rate, 3) the neutral gas mass fraction, and 4) the dynamical mass using the CO line width.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Astronomy, Minnesota, University of

Goddard Space Flight Center, National Aeronautics and Space Administration
